Brexit petition in just over 24 hoursMore than 250,000 people&nbspin just over 24 hours have signed The Independent’s petition&nbspdemanding a Final Say referendum on the Brexit deal.Politicians backing the campaign launched earlier this week said the sudden flood of people wanting to put their names down pointed to a growing well of support for another national vote on Brexit.Those backing the campaign included senior figures from all the major parties, such as former Tory cabinet minister Justine Greening, ex-prime minister Tony Blair, Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable, Green leader Caroline Lucas and many others.Former Conservative&nbspattorney general&nbspDominic Grieve, Labour’s&nbspChuka Umunna, Lib Dem MP&nbspLayla Moran, campaigner&nbspGina Miller&nbspand ex-Labour spin doctor&nbspAlastair Campbell&nbspare among those who have already backed the campaign.The backing comes as Facebook released details of scores of online ads – including misleading claims about NHS spending and immigration from Turkey – targeted at its users by Brexiteers during the 2016 referendum.The Independent kicked off its campaign for a Final Say on whatever Brexit terms emerge, along with a petition, earlier this week.Ex-cabinet minister Ms Greening said: “I believe that putting the final decision on Brexit in the hands of the British people is the only way to break parliament’s impasse, and the right way to decide our country’s future.“That’s why The Independent’s campaign is so vital and has my support – anyone who feels the same should back it.”The Independent’s campaign is so vital and has my support – anyone who feels the same should back itShe spoke as Ms May still looks unlikely to be able to pass any Brexit plans through the House of Commons easily because of&nbspher wafer thin majority.Earlier in the day British and European Union&nbspnegotiators in Brussels also&nbspgave downbeat assessments about&nbspthe state of negotiations.The EU’s chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said there remains “major issues to be discussed and questions to be answered”, and rejected Ms May’s customs plans, while Brexit secretary Dominic&nbspRaab added: “To be frank, we are not at the end of the road yet.”Chuka Umunna and John Rentoul debate the possibility of another Brexit referendumWith an economically devastating no-deal Brexit looking ever more likely, Mr Blair took to Twitter to give his support to The Independent’s campaign.He said: “33m+ people voted in the EU referendum wanting a better country, not to be poorer, not to put further pressure on our already stretched health service, not for job losses or to stockpile food and medicines. It should be your&nbsp#Finalsay.”This vote must include an option for an exit from Brexit I congratulate The Independent for joining this campaign. It’s both a brave and correct moveTheresa May&nbsphas urged voters not to worry about&nbspBrexit, despite her government setting out plans to stockpile food, blood and medicine in case it goes badly.She said people should take “reassurance and comfort” from news of the plans, to be implemented if the UK crashes out of the EU without an agreement in March.Health secretary Matt Hancock has admitted he had already met with industry leaders&nbspto discuss building up NHS reserves&nbspof vaccinations, medical devices, clinical consumables and blood products if Britain crashes out of the EU without a deal, while Mr Raab also recently&nbspconfirmed preparations were being made to stockpile food.Sir Vince said: “The Liberal Democrats have been fighting for the British people to have the final say on any Brexit deal, or worse still, no deal. This vote must include an option for an exit from Brexit.“I congratulate The Independent for joining this campaign. It’s both a brave and correct move.”Readers’ view: The Independent’s campaign for a Brexit referendumProtesters try to help Boris Johnson move from ‘grace-and-favour’ pad25 comments from our petition for a second Brexit referendumBrexit shows the young were right to vote Remain – we need a final sayMusicians ‘won’t perform in UK due to post-Brexit vote visa process’Britain could cancel Brexit and stay in EU on same terms, France saysFormer Lib Dem leader Tim Farron said The Independent joining the campaign for the people to have a final say on Brexit could “prove to be a turning point in this saga”.Green leader Caroline Lucas said the case for a People’s Vote – the parallel campaign for another referendum on the outcome of the Brexit negotiations – is growing stronger every day.“As the government descends into further chaos and parliament appears gridlocked, it’s increasingly clear that the only way to resolve the situation is through a People’s Vote.”Brexit Resignation: July 10th “misleading” by the official statistician – that the UK hands £350m&nbspa week to the EU which could otherwise be spent on the NHS.Other ads repeatedly made dubious claims that Turkey and Albania would soon join the EU and that millions of their citizens would flood into the UK.Eloise Todd, chief executive of Best for Britain, which campaigns to keep the UK open to EU membership, said: “We need a People’s Vote to tell the government it has taken the wrong path through the Brexit process.&nbspSo the news that The Independent has come out to support the campaign feels like a real turning point.“Theresa May is in office, but Jacob&nbspRees-Mogg&nbspis in power.&nbspIt is time the people took back control. I would urge everyone to back the campaign and sign the petition. We voted on departure, let the people vote on the destination.”Labour MP David Lammy, who has called for a second referendum since 2016, said it was clear even then that the Leave campaign – which has been&nbspfined by police after breaking spending rules – was based on wild assertions.He added: “The Independent’s new push for a referendum on the final Brexit deal&nbspsits, with other similar campaigns,&nbspon the right side of history.“Allowing the public to choose whether we remain in the EU –&nbspor indeed choose, in full knowledge, to become poorer, less sovereign and diplomatically neutered –&nbspis the only democratic solution to this political nightmare.”Labour’s Geraint Davies&nbspsaid: “Thanks to broken promises, cheating and incompetent negotiations, what people reasonably expected from voting to leave won’t be fulfilled, and this decision will affect future generations.&nbspIt’s critical that people are given the final say.”Lib Dem MP Christine Jardine said: “It’s becoming clearer every day that we deserve the opportunity to have a final say on the deal, and whether or not it is what people actually wanted.“Even people who voted to leave are telling me what is on the table now is not necessarily what they wanted. We deserve the chance to have a final say and we should be demanding it.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereEnter your email addressFill out this fieldor register with your social accountAlready have an account? story: Created with Sketch.Czech Republic latest to echo European Commission's negotiating lineClick to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May’s attempt to bypass Brussels in Brexit talks fails as member states line up to back official EU positionBritish attempts to bypass the European Commission in Brexit talks by dealing directly with member states are failing, as national governments line up to back the official EU position.The Czech Republic, a traditional British ally, was the latest to endorse the Brussels line on Friday, just hours after chief negotiator Michel Barnier ruled out the EU agreeing to the Chequers customs plan.Brexiteers in government have become transfixed with the idea that the European Commission is the roadblock to progress in Brexit talks and that member states would agree to make concessions to Britain – if only they were allowed.Despite a lack of evidence for this analysis, the government has tried in vain to make direct overtures to other EU states, with limited success.Theresa May is set to meet Czech PM Andrej Babis on Friday, but ahead of the visit Mr Babis echoed the commission’s concerns with the UK’s Chequers proposal almost word for word.“There is a clear problem with the fact that the EU will not have a mechanism to control its borders and it would be delegated – without any EU control – to a third country, which would be Britain after March,” he told the BBC before the meeting.Mr Babis also suggested the UK proposals on single market regulations lacked&nbsp “a certain balance between the rights and obligations”.There is a clear problem with the fact that the EU will not have a mechanism to control its bordersThe Czech Republic is only the latest member state to disagree. Sources familiar with the French position told the UK that officials in Paris were “puzzled” at why the EU would be expected to accept a British customs plan that was so complex, risky and burdensome for it and its businesses, to no benefit.Nathalie Loiseau, France’s European affairs minister, said: “There should be no mistake. Michel Barnier does not represent only the Commission. He is the negotiator for the European Union.“He gets his mandate and his guidelines from the heads of state and government. And we have discussed it regularly at the level of ministers. We meet with Michel Barnier on a regular basis.&nbsp“So do the heads of state and government. So there is no difference between what Michel Barnier says and what we would say inidually, each and every member state.”Brexit so far: in picturesBoris Johnson MP, Labour MP Gisela Stuart and UKIP MP Douglas Carswell address the people of Stafford in Market Square during the Vote Leave Brexit Battle Bus tour on 17 May 2016. story: Created with Sketch.The Independent&nbsphas launched a&nbspcampaign for the electorate to have a final say on the exit termsClick to followIndy PoliticsFinal say: Majority of students would support a vote on the final Brexit deal, new poll showsThe majority of students would back a vote on the final&nbspBrexit&nbspdeal, as some 70 per cent believe they will be worse off after leaving the EU, a new poll shows.Support among young voters for a new referendum has surged from 58 per cent in February 2017 to 67 per cent this month, according to a survey of undergraduates conducted by Youthsight, the UK's largest youth research group.The new poll found that seven out of 10 students think their prospects will change for the worse after Brexit, compared to 13 per cent who think they will be better off on leaving the EU.It comes as&nbspThe Independent&nbsplaunched its&nbspFinal Say&nbspcampaign to call for a public vote on the Brexit deal, which attracted more than 200,000 supporters in the first 24 hours.The ongoing turmoil over Theresa May's Brexit approach has left&nbsp77 per cent of students of the view the government is doing a bad job with&nbspthe negotiations.Support for MPs determining the final deal has also fallen from 25 per cent in February 2017 to 17 per cent this month,&nbspimplying that young people are increasingly losing faith in those in parliament’s ability to deliver a positive outcome.&nbsp&nbspBrexit will affect the decision of 60 per cent of students likely to vote in a future general election, the survey shows, while half of those would be willing to vote tactically in the future in order to achieve their preferred Brexit outcome.The findings will heap pressure on Jeremy Corbyn's party over&nbspits Brexit stance, as nearly eight out of 10 Labour-supporting students said they would be more likely to vote for a party that opposes leaving the EU.Younger voters&nbsphelped to boost&nbspLabour&nbspin the polls during last year's snap election, leaving the Tories scrambling to improve their offer to young people.Brexit Resignation: July 10th 2018 Maria Caulfield MP Conservative Party's vice chair for women final Brexit deal. But more than that what this polling shows is that students in places like Canterbury, who helped Jeremy Corbyn win those seats and confound his critics, expect him to oppose Brexit.These young people are worried about the future and expect the Labour Party to do its job and oppose this shambolic government.This polling by YouthSight shows that Labour need to move their position. title: new jersey radio hosts suspended attorney general turban man gurbir grewal
story: Created with Sketch.Comments on conservative-leaning talk show drew criticism from state governor and senatorClick to followThe Independent USUS radio hosts suspended for calling first Sikh state attorney general ‘turban man’Two hosts of a talk radio programme in New Jersey have been suspended after referring to the state's attorney general, Gurbir Grewal, as Turban man during a segment on Wednesday. Mr Grewal is Sikh.Dennis Malloy and Judi Franco, who host a conservative-leaning talk show every day from 10am to 2pm on New Jersey 101.5 FM, will be off the air for 10 days, the station announced.We take these comments seriously and echo Dennis and Judi's sincere apology to Attorney General Grewal and his family, as well as the Sikh and Asian communities, Ron deCastro, the station's president, said in a statement posted on its website. Dennis and Judi are known for their plainspoken brand of humour, but in this case, the language used was clearly demeaning and inappropriate.Mr Grewal, a first-generation American who grew up in Essex, New Jersey, became the country's first Sikh state attorney general when he took office earlier this year. Mr Malloy and Ms Franco were discussing his recent order to suspend marijuana prosecutions in the state when Mr Malloy said he would never know Mr Grewal's name and would just call him the guy with the turban.Yeah, turban man, Mr Malloy said. And listen if that offends you, then don't wear the turban, man. I'll remember your name.The comments drew strong rebukes from Governor Phil Murphy, Senator Cory Booker and the state's ACLU chapter, which tweeted: Racism isn't cute. It's just racist.Outraged by the abhorrent and xenophobic comments mocking @NewJerseyOAG on The @DennisandJudi Show, Mr Murphy, a Democrat who appointed Mr Grewal, wrote on Twitter. Hate speech has no place in NJ, and does not belong on our airwaves.Mr Grewal responded as well.My name, for the record, is Gurbir Grewal, he wrote on Twitter. I'm the 61st Attorney General of NJ. I'm a Sikh American. I have 3 daughters. And yesterday, I told them to turn off the radio.Sikhs in the United States have been the target of slurs and hate crimes and are sometimes confused with Muslims. Men who follow the religion typically wear a beard and turban.Mr Grewal also shared a video from a speech he gave at the Asian Pacific American Institute for Congressional Studies in which he talked about the ways racism had affected his political career.Scroll through any of the online comments about my work or my office or any news story, it can really be stomach turning, he said, noting that he'd been receiving death threats since he became attorney general. I have been called a towel-head, a raghead, a terrorist.In an interview with the New York Times last year as he prepared to take office, he spoke about how he was harassed after September 11 by a stranger who would wait outside of his office and shout, I've found him, I've found bin Laden!Mr Malloy issued an apology to Mr Grewal and the East Asian community in New Jersey on Thursday afternoon.Speaking on behalf of Judi and myself today in offering our heartfelt apologies to the attorney general of the state of New Jersey, who is a man who certainly deserves more respect than our comments reflected on Wednesday, Mr Malloy said in a video apology. I made a mistake on Wednesday in saying something that was out of bounds and it was wrong.The station's parent company, Townsquare Media, declined to comment.Family of murdered Sikh man blames Trump policies for 'racial hatred'Sikh community saves Fourth of July fireworks display with $10,000Racist Snapchat story targeting Sikh man on flight sparks outrage Sikhs ask for hate-crime probe after man told 'go back home'NYPD to allow Sikh officers to wear turban on duty According to NorthJersey, the two hosts are known for their blunt talk on everyday issues with a conservative slant. They have defended President Trump and made fun of National Public Radio and former 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick, while mixing in light-hearted banter and talk about the mundane aspects of everyday life, according to the website.Multiple callers phoning into the station during Mr Malloy and Ms Franco's slot on Thursday defended the hosts' remarks, according to NJ.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldor register with your social accountAlready have an account? story: Created with Sketch.Former international captain has vowed to lift country out of poverty, combat corruption and protect rights of minorities and women. None of this is easy to doClick to followThe Independent OnlineFrom cricketing legend to prime minister of Pakistan, the rise of Imran KhanAfter more than two decades of political campaigning, much of it spent in the political wilderness, Imran Khan will finally become Prime Minister of Pakistan. Along the way, as his ex-wife Jemima Khan&nbspnoted on Twitter, he endured “humiliations, hurdles and sacrifices”. Now, the former cricket legend and philanthropist could become one of the most powerful civilian leaders the country has known.Older readers will of course be familiar with him. After playing cricket for Oxford while he studied politics, philosophy and economics at Keble College, Khan became one of the best known Pakistanis in Britain. He figured prominently in tabloids for his social life, was often spotted at exclusive private members clubs like Annabel’s and Tramp.&nbspHe&nbspbefriended Mick Jagger, Sting and Goldie Hawn while being on nodding terms with Prince Charles and other royals. He married Jemima Goldsmith, the journalist and filmmaker sister of Zac, and invited Princess Diana to Pakistan.For Pakistanis, Khan was one of the few people who did them proud. Winning the Cricket World Cup in 1992 was a rare moment when Pakistan distinguished itself internationally. Pakistanis had grown weary of being principally depicted as a Third World basket case beset by social problems where women, minorities and the poor were treated appallingly. At times when boorish and condescending English cricketers like Ian Botham described Pakistan as “a place to send your mother-in-law”, Khan confronted that racism publicly.Pakistanis craved a confident, good-looking spokesman and the former cricketer could play the part. It’s one of the reasons why many voted for him.“I believe Oxford educated Imran Khan can stand toe to toe with world leaders and make a strong case for Pakistan,” wrote Haroon, a Pakistani singer and one of many celebrities, including cricketers, singers and actors who backed him.&nbspBut he was also supported by a bewildering array of people from religious conservative backgrounds, wealthy businessmen, grafters from the middle classes, taxi drivers and factory workers.Khan is many things to many people. Central to his appeal is that he has not been in power before. It was common to hear his supporters say: “We’ve tried the others”,&nbspreferring to the parties of former prime ministers Benazir Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif, “let’s try him this time”.&nbspFor people alarmed at endemic levels of corruption, Khan represents a rare, honest and financially “clean” leader valiantly battling against an entrenched venal order. For religious conservatives and nationalists, he soothes feelings of injured pride and rouses their spirits.There are people whose support he should be embarrassed by. Sara Taseer, a Singapore-based entrepreneur, declared herself appalled by the sight of poor Baluch women lining up to vote. “Love seeing this turnout of women,” she tweeted, “but then I think would I allow these ladies to make a decision even about what be cooking in my kitchen today? And these ladies will decide on the future of the nation. Scary thought.”And there are supporters he should stay clear of. Asad Umar, Khan’s finance minister to be, posted photos of himself courting the support of Fazlur Rehman Khalil, someone whose name is on a US&nbspterror watchlist.Khan’s rhetoric is often studded with references to the plight of the poor and the ravages of the elite. “A country shouldn’t be measured by how its wealthiest live,” he said in his first speech after the election, “but by how its poorest people are treated.” Critics say that message is at odds with the composition of his party, which is dominated by some of the wealthiest people in Pakistani politics. Many of Khan’s candidates this time around were also drawn from conventional old parties or military regimes, undermining the claim that their election will herald a “new Pakistan”.There are contradictions people notice in Khan's own pronouncements. When I interviewed him for The Independent, he came across as thoughtful, polite, serious and even good-humoured. On the campaign trail, however, he was seen as boastful and arrogant – making crude jibes against his opponents, taunting voters who support his rivals as “donkeys”, and denouncing liberals as “bloodthirsty”. He has forcefully denounced terrorism, and yet has been accused of being soft on the Taliban. Khan was a critic of Pakistan’s blasphemy laws and has defended religious minorities, but more recently vowed to protect the laws and accused his opponents of being part of a foreign plot to undermine it.When I first came to Pakistan to report for The Independent, Khan was a fierce critic of General Pervez Musharraf’s military rule. I saw him on the streets supporting an independent judiciary, interviewed him the night before he was arrested for defying emergency rule, heard him speak out against attacks on the press, enforced disappearances, civilian casualties in military offensives, and covered his protests against CIA drone strikes. Those experiences do not easily reconcile with the image of him as a mere shill for the Pakistan army.As prime minister, Khan will want to be the most powerful leader in the country. That distinction has usually belonged to the head of the army, which has ruled the country directly for three decades and wielded its clout backstage for the rest. It will be interesting to see how he negotiates these structural tensions. Some of the areas of dispute between Khan and the army have faded: drone strikes are rare, military operations he opposed are a thing of the past, and the US-led, Pakistan-backed “war on terror” is all but over.So, how will Khan rule? As a crusader against corruption and champion of the poor, or as an angry demagogue? Will he strengthen Pakistan’s feeble civilian institutions or disappear into the shadows of the military? Can he unite all the different Pakistanis he appealed to this afternoon, or will he seek to deepen the dangerous political isions that this election has revealed? Will Pakistan pursue peace with its neighbours, or will old modes of chest-beating belligerence endure?Only time will tell. The speech he made this afternoon pleasantly surprised many: he vowed to lift the country out of poverty to combat corruption – starting by hold himself and his own cabinet accountable he said he would educate the more than 25 million children out of school and he said he would protect the rights of minorities and women. None of this is easy to do. There are strong reasons to believe Khan won’t be able to. But it would be good to see him try.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldor register with your social accountAlready have an account? story: Created with Sketch.‘How will&nbspImran&nbspKhan bring the change he has promised with all these old faces?’Click to followThe Independent OnlineMahesh Kumar Malani of the PPP has become the first non-Muslim to win a general seat in the national assembly of PakistanPakistan has elected a non-Muslim to a general seat in the national assembly for the first time in its recent history, even as the victory of ex-cricketer Imran Khan raises some concerns among minority communities.Mahesh Kumar Malani, a 55-year-old Hindu, spoke to The Independent on Friday after it was confirmed that he had won his seat in the impoverished Tharparkar district of Sindh province.As a member of the third-placed progressive Pakistan People’s Party, led by the son of assassinated former prime minister Benazir Bhutto, Mr Malani said he will now likely travel to Islamabad in opposition to Mr Khan’s Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI).Near-final results late on Friday showed PTI had won 115 of the 272 contested seats in the national assembly, while the incumbent Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) conceded defeat on 62. PPP placed third, with 43 seats.And while coalition talks for Mr Khan to form a government are just beginning, Mr Malani was willing to get a headstart on taking the victorious former sportsman – whose critics dub him “Taliban Khan” for his perceived closeness to extremist Islamist groups – to task.Standing up for minority rights represents one of the key tenets of the PPP manifesto, Mr Malani said, but he would not let his religion alone define his role in parliament.From cricketing legend to Pakistan PM, the rise of Imran KhanImran Khan’s supporters dance in the street as he declares victoryOnce a saviour, Imran Khan is just the least bad option in PakistanHere’s what we can expect of Pakistan’s likely new leader, Imran Khan“I am not only the representative of the Hindu or the minority,” he said. “In a general election the Muslim majority also votes for me, so I am going to perform my duty for all&nbspmy people and for my nation. My agenda is to stand up for the rights of every citizen of Pakistan.”On the campaign trail, Mr Khan rallied support from mostly Muslims with populist messages calling for the death penalty for blasphemers and vitriol against neighbouring India.Most voters from religious minorities told The Independent on election day that they would vote for PML-N over Mr Khan’s PTI. Nadeem Masih, 30, from Islamabad’s small Christian community, said of Mr Khan: “He is not interested in our rights if I tell you the truth.”For Mr Malani, the biggest issue with Mr Khan was not necessarily his courting of extremists, but rather his courting of independent candidates who regularly swap parties for elections to join the highest bidder – a group of influential, veteran How are they now not corrupt, but have become honest and sincere?”Mr Malani said it was nonetheless time for people to come together in the best interests of the country. He praised his campaign team of mostly Muslim workers and said he hoped soon other political parties would pick candidates like PPP “on merit, with no discrimination towards religion or any other basis”.And while he said he will “do what I can” as a member of the opposition to Mr Khan, his final words for the new prime minister elect were reconciliatory, adding: “Despite all the reservations, my best wishes are with him.”Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Created with Sketch.The first woman to be awarded the International Master title went on to save children in LeningradClick to followThe Independent OnlineLyudmila Rudenko: Five things you didn't know about the inspirational Soviet chess championLyudmila&nbspRudenko, one of the world's most influential chess players,&nbspwas born 114 years ago today.Born in&nbsp1904 in the city of Lubny, then part of the Russian Empire and now in&nbspcentral Ukraine, she would go on to win the highest honour in the game.&nbspNow, Google has celebrated the chess master’s legacy with a Doodle which takes artistic inspiration from 1960’s graphic art and posters.Double world champion refuses to defend titles in Saudi ArabiaTwitter 280-character limit lets users play Tetris and Chess in tweetsHere are five facts about the chess supremo.&nbsp1. She was the first woman awarded the International Master title&nbspIntroduced to the game by her father at the age of 10, Rudenko&nbspemerged&nbspas a world class player in&nbspthe late 1920's, placing fifth&nbspin the 1928 Moscow Women’s Championship.&nbspShe went onto become the second Women’s World Chess Champion in 1950 and maintained her grip on the title for three years.&nbsp&nbspWhen she lost it to fellow Russian&nbspElisaveta&nbspBykova. she completed the tournament with a record of five wins, seven losses and two draws.Google said&nbspits doodle “reimagines&nbspa focused&nbspRudenko’s determination during the world championship game”.Rudenko was named an International Master of chess in 1950, and a Woman Grandmaster in 1976, 10 years before she died.&nbspShe was inducted into the World Chess Hall of Fame in 2015.2. She also had a great zeal for swimmingRudenko was initially enthralled with swimming and&nbspwon a local competition in the women’s 400-meter breaststroke in Odessa.&nbspIt was after that triumphant swim that she set off to Moscow where she cultivated her flair for chess.By 1925&nbspshe had managed to become the&nbspswimming vice-champion of Ukraine in her chosen stroke.World news in picturesA house burns during the Carr fire in Redding, California. story: Created with Sketch.United Nations has urged both sides to 'step back from the brink of war'&nbsp– your questions answered about latest flare-up in violence&nbspClick to followThe Independent OnlineA fireball exploding in Gaza City during Israeli bombardment on July 20  Q. Why has there been an upsurge in violence?At the heart of the latest escalation is 16 weeks of Palestinian protests that have taken place at the border fence between Gaza and Israel. &nbspSince 30 March, hundreds of thousands of Gazans have marched each week on the heavily fortified border&nbspdemanding the right to return to lands they fled and were forced from after the 1948 war, which resulted in the formation of Israel.Palestinians, who have suffered for over a decade under a crippling blockade, have said they are&nbsppeacefully demonstrating during the Great March of Return marches, which is their right. But Israel has accused Hamas, the proscribed militant group that runs the enclave, of encouraging protesters to be violent towards their soldiers, to cut the border fence and to launch raids inside Israel.&nbspThe Israeli military has responded with live fire, leaving more than 140 Palestinians dead, and many more with life changing injuries, in moves described by the UN General Assembly as excessive, disproportionate and indiscriminate”.&nbspAt the same time, protesters say, in frustration, they have taken to launching burning kites and balloons laden with incendiary devices across the border, setting alight to over 2,600 hectares of Israeli farmland and causing hundreds of thousands of pounds of damage.&nbspThe Israeli army, that said its citizens near to Gaza are in danger, subsequently tightened an 11-year-old blockade on the strip, closing Kerem Shalom, the sole goods crossing between Israel and Gaza, and strangling Gaza’s fishing zones to just three nautical miles, a third of what it was before the protests. Israel said earlier this week that it would allow fuel and gas to be transferred via Kerem Shalom, and widen the fishing lanes, partially lifting the restrictions, should a shaky ceasefire hold.&nbspNeither side to date will back down, saying their respective responses are fair and legitimate. This has created a cycle of violence that has reached boiling in the last week, with warnings from the UN that a war could break out.Q. Why is the UN fearful there could be another war? &nbspOn Friday, 20 July, Israeli Staff Sergeant Aviv Levi, 21, was killed by what the Israeli army called a “violent raid” during the protests.&nbspIt marked the first time an Israeli soldier was killed by Palestinian gunfire near Gaza since the last war in 2014 and so crossed a definitive red line. Israel said that gunmen had shot at and lobbed grenades at its soldiers. It responded by bombarding Gaza with tank and air fire, and said its forces struck 60 “military sites” run by Hamas.Four Palestinians were killed that day. Palestinian health officials said that at least one was a civilian. Earlier in the month, there was the most intense exchange of fire between Gaza militants and Israel since the 2014 war - largely due to the border protests.&nbspEgypt has intervened several times enforcing ceasefires which keep being broken.&nbspGazans protest as US embassy moves to Jerusalem – in picturesPalestinian mourners carry the dead body of Mukhtar Ebu Hamas, 25, killed by Israeli forces in Gaza on 14 MayA Palestinian woman flashes a victory sign during a protest near the border fence Israeli soldiers guard on top of a watch tower along the Israel-Gaza borderPalestinian demonstrators react to fired tear gasPalestinian demonstrators run for coverUS President's daughter Ivanka Trump and her husband Senior White House Advisor Jared Kushner arrive for the controversial inauguration of the US embassy in Jerusalem. that have been violated, Antonio Guterres, the UN&nbspsecretary-general, warned that they were on the “brink of a devastating conflict”. He said it was “imperative” both Israelis and Palestinians abide by the ceasefire.On Monday,&nbspZeid Ra'ad Al Hussein, the UN’s human rights chief, called for an investigation into Israel’s actions at the border calling the most recent killings “shocking”. He said it was also vital to address the root causes of the Gaza demonstrations which would continue, as living conditions under Israel’s blockade are “grossly inadequate”.&nbspPalestinians in Gaza, including the armed factions, say the Israeli security forces have used live ammunition against peaceful protesters, and launched devastating airstrikes on the strip, killing dozens of people. They said that Israel has also exacerbated a humanitarian and economic crisis within the enclave by adding the new restrictions.&nbspIsrael maintains Hamas, that it regards as a terrorist group, has incited violence and endangered the lives of Israelis near the border. It says the fires caused by the burning kites have caused significant damage to farm land.Q. Who are the protagonists?The main protagonists are Israel and its army, and the myriad armed factions within Gaza, that answer to a central operations room that is ostensibly led by the militant arm of Hamas – called the Qassem Brigades. Within that are vastly different factions, with anything ranging from small far-left Marxist armed groups like the National Resistance Brigades to Islamic jihad’s al-Quds Brigade.&nbspQ. What is at stake?For this region, everything. In the last war more than 2,200 Palestinians, and 73 Israelis, were killed. Gaza took several years to recover and still has not been fully rebuilt. More fundamentally is the moribund Middle East peace process, which is arguably dragging into its eighth decade. A new devastating war would only put another nail in its coffin.&nbspEgypt, that has long held a position as mediator in the Israel-Palestine conflict, has reportedly intervened multiple times in the past few weeks to broker a ceasefire. Last week&nbspHamas said it once again stepped in and brokered a truce but it keeps being broken.&nbspMost recently on Wednesday, Israel fired a barrage of tank and artillery shells at what it identified as military targets within Gaza, after one of its soldiers was injured during an earlier cross-border exchange of fire. Three Palestinians were killed during the tank fire,&nbspHamas&nbspconfirmed the dead were members of its group.&nbspQ. What is going to happen now?Both sides of the conflict, as well as civilians, have repeatedly expressed an interest in stopping the current escalation from tumbling into a full-blown war. Further deaths will only worsen the situation.Q. But if neither side wants war why does the violence continue?&nbspHamas is in a tricky position. Gaza is experiencing one of the most severe economic crises in its recent history. There are many reasons, including the Israeli blockade, new sanctions from the Palestinian Authority which is dominated by Hamas’ secular political rival Fatah and a massive shortfall in International aid funding.&nbspIn a bid to force Hamas to relinquish power over Gaza, last April the PA ordered early retirement for nearly a third of its 60,000 Gaza employees as well as restrictions on electricity access to Gaza. In May it slashed salaries to its civil servants in the enclave by at least 20 percent, piling on more pressure.&nbspCash-strapped Hamas, that once relied on taxing goods smuggled through tunnels to Egypt, has also been unable to pay its own 40,000 employees in full.Meanwhile the United Nation’s refugee agency UNRWA said it is suffering from an “unprecedented” £164 million funding shortfall, after the US said it was slashing more than 80 percent of its &nbspfunding to the agency. This has only exacerbated&nbspthe problems. This week UNRWA&nbspannounced it was getting rid of&nbsp250 jobs in the Palestinian Territories, including more than 100 in Gaza.&nbspThe 1.8 million residents&nbspof Gaza, who are&nbspalready suffering from one of the highest jobless rates in the world, cannot sustain further devastation and many are increasingly frustrated with their own leaders.&nbspMembers of Hamas’s Palestinian political rivals in Gaza have told The Independent that Hamas wants the focus of Gazans' anger to be directed towards Israel, which it regards as an occupier, rather than at local government and themselves.&nbspAnd therefore, the protests at the border cannot stop.&nbspIsrael, meanwhile, is facing a potential war at its northern border as well as its frontier with Gaza. &nbspOver the last months, Israel has been increasingly concerned by Iran’s attempts to build permanent military infrastructure near Israel in Syria, where Tehran is backing Syrian President Assad and the rebels. Iran and its allied forces have fired into Israel.&nbspMembers of the Israeli army and government have told The Independent they have no interest in fighting a war on two fronts. But at the same time Israel is facing pressure from its own people to stop the burning kites and violence at the border.&nbspIt all depends on whether the Egyptian-brokered truces can hold.&nbspGreat March of ReturnEnter your email addressFill out this fieldor register with your social accountAlready have an account? title: Goldfish health swimming upside down swim bladder disorder
story: If a goldfish is swimming upside down, it could have a swim bladder disorder (Image: getty)A upside-down swimming is a common problem in goldfish and the cause is a disorder of the swim bladder.&nbspThis specialised organ enables a fish to modify its buoyancy so it can e or surface according to its needs.&nbspFat-bodied goldfish are at risk because their swim bladder can become compressed.&nbspBacterial, viral and parasitic disease can be to blame but most frequently the issue is down to feeding problems.&nbsp                Britain's biggest GOLDFISH? Red oranda weighs more than a bag of SUGAR                Shock as HUNDREDS of goldfish left to suffocate in dried out pond b...Flakes or floating pellets may lead to the goldfish ingesting air with its food while other diets can cause constipation or fermentation in the gut.&nbspMany problems associated with pet goldfish are also related to poor water quality, including build-up of contaminants such as nitrites or ammonia, infrequent cycling of water and sudden changes of temperature.&nbspAn aquarium expert and your vet will be able to advise how to monitor water quality and also on appropriate non-floating food.&nbspIf the water quality is good, you could try stopping feeding for 24 hours, which may allow the problem to right itself.&nbspFind out more at fishvetsociety.org.uk&nbsp&#9679&nbspDavid Grant MBE was a vet at the RSPCA Harmsworth Hospital for Animals.&nbspWrite to him at Express Yourself, 10 Lower Thames Street, London EC3R 6EN.&nbspHe is unable to enter into inidual correspondence

story: Archibald, the albino kangaroo, and its mother (Image: CEN)In the photos the albino kangaroo, a male named Archibald, can be seen standing with his mother.Other images show the baby kangaroo inside his mother's pouch and the images were shared on the zoo's social media page.Archibald, or Archi for short, is not the first albino kangaroo to be born in the zoo and joins a two-year-old female albino called Piksi.Employees from the zoo told local media that the baby kangaroo was born a few months ago but because he was inside his mother's pouch his white fur had not been noticed by the zoo-keepers.                Thugs kill kangaroo, dress it in leopardskin and tie it to chair                Police capture runaway kangaroo helped to escape by goat accompliceThe baby kangaroo inside his mother's pouch (Image: CEN)Zoo visitors pat Archibald (Image: CEN)Albinism, which is caused by a genetic mutation, is extremely rare in kangaroos, similar to other species.According to mammologist Mark Eldridge from the Australian Museum white or albino kangaroos only occur once every 50,000 to 100,000 animals.Albino kangaroos rarely survive to adulthood in the wild because their fur does not provide them with camouflage.Kangaroos are indigenous to Australia.Female kangaroos have a pouch called a marsupium in which joeys complete postnatal development.

story: Professor of European Politics and Foreign Affairs Anand Menon says that although some arguments for a another vote are that the facts are clearer and the arguments are more advanced, it still wouldn&rsquot matter.He said: &ldquoAny referendum held before the UK leaves the EU would not be held on a clear plan for future UK-EU relations.&nbsp&ldquoAs the clock ticks down to the article 50 deadline, there are real doubts as to whether sufficient time remains to finalise even a withdrawal agreement, let alone a clear outline of a future relationship.Mr Menon also says a second referendum would generate anger by the Leave voters and they would feel cheated.                BREXIT LIVE: Theresa May heads to Austria for crunch EU exit talks                May's strategy DOOMED as Czech minister says PM won't find EU cracksHe said: &ldquoThe polls reveals a public stubbornly ided, and despite a shift towards a slight majority believing that the vote to leave was the wrong decision, the margin is still small enough to prevent any certainty as to the outcome of any popular vote.&ldquoWhatever the result, it seems unlikely to provide a significant majority either way.A second referendum would not solve any of the underlying problems that led to the Brexit vote in the first place.He said: &ldquoIt would provide grist to the mill to opponents of the EU, and the establishment would be portrayed as having betrayed leave voters.A Brexit expert claims we shouldn't have a second referendum (Image: )Mr Menon adds that a second referendum would not guarantee a decisive vote just because Parliament is gridlocked.He said: &ldquoThe irony is that our representatives are indeed representative of the British people.&nbsp&ldquoNeither in Westminster nor among the public at large can a majority be found for any one Brexit outcome.Furthermore, logistically a second referendum will just be messier than the first if it was carried out before the March 2019 deadline.Thousands take to the streets of London for Brexit march.                    PA1 of 21People took to the streets of London to march for a second EU referendumHe writes in : &ldquoRemember, the bill for the 2016 referendum took seven months to pass.&nbsp&ldquoAdd the time required to designate the campaigns and hold the vote itself (and even allowing for &lsquocutting and pasting&rsquo some of the parliamentary work from 2015 to speed things up), and it is clear that it would be difficult to have a result before the UK&rsquos date of departure from the EU on 29 March 2019.Former education secretary Justine Greening has claimed that the public should get another vote to under Brexit.The Putney MP told BBC Radio 4's Today she would campaign for Remain in any new vote. Asked if any other senior Tories backed a second referendum, she said: Yes I believe so.Anand Menon has said it would be a disaster if there was a second referendum (Image: TWITTER)Justine Greening has called for a second referendum (Image: )Discussing the Prime Minister's Chequers plan for Brexit she said: I don't think it can work. I think it was a genuine clever attempt at a compromise that could work.But in practice having looked through the detail now it just won't and I cannot see how, going forward, the common rulebook will be workable in practice.What we need is a clear route forward that settles this European question once and for all.But Downing Street made it clear that it will not reopen the referendum.A spokesman for the Prime Minister said: &ldquoThe British public have voted to leave the EU. There is not going to be a second referendum under any circumstances.

story: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry have revealed their royal monogram  (Image:  )The Duke and Duchess of Sussex&rsquos new regal cypher depicts both of their initials, which intertwines an M and a H, underneath a coronet.The monogram, which will now be seen on all official paperwork coming out of Kensington Palace, is in royal blue - a nod to Harry&rsquos late mother Princess Diana.Royal fans caught a glimpse of the couple&rsquos new monogram on Australian TV show &lsquoThe Today Show&rsquo when presenter Georgie Gardner showed off a letter she had received from Harry and Meghan.Ms Gardener was lucky enough to receive a thank you note from the duke and duchess after she sent them a picnic blanket as a present for their May Royal Wedding. We are incredibly touched. All the best, Harry and Meghan.Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's monogram has been revealed  (Image: THE TODAY SHOW )Meghan Markle and Harry embrace after a charity polo match  (Image: WIREIMAGE )The monogram is very similar to that of Meghan Markle&rsquos own, which as released back in May, featuring a script black &lsquoM&rsquo with a coronet.&nbspEach member of the Royal Family has his or her own cypher, a type of logo, such as the Queen&rsquos ERII, made from their initials in a tradition dating back to Tudor times.The couple&rsquos joint royal cypher is exactly the same colour as the duke&rsquos inidual monogram.The crown above the initial appears to be one approved by a Royal Warrant of 1917 for the sons and daughters of the heir apparent.Meghan, Duchess of Sussex and Prince Harry attend the Sentebale Polo 2018 held at the Royal County of Berkshire Polo Club                    REUTERS1 of 16Newlywed Meghan gives husband Harry a congratulatory smooch after handing him the winning trophy&nbspIt also features two crosses pat&eacutee (a type of Christian cross), four fleurs-de-lys, and two strawberry leaves.And Prince Harry&rsquos cypher was said to be deliberately chosen to resemble Princess Diana&rsquos in motif and almost the exact same colour.A Royal aide said: &ldquoIt&rsquos a very touching way for him to pay tribute to his late mother.

title: NASA pictures mars photos moon landing images
story: Influential photographs show NASA&rsquos achievements including the famous footprints on the first moon landing, the first colour image of the Earth taken by the Apollo 8 astronauts, and an extraordinary image of Ed White who became the first American to conduct a spacewalk.The National Aeronautics and Space Act, which led to the creation of NASA, was signed into law by US President Dwight D Eisenhower on July 29, 1958.As well as the moon landing in 1969, NASA has sent rovers to Mars and explored the solar system with numerous probes, used telescopes to peer deep into the far reaches of space and joined with other countries, including Russia, in building and maintaining the International Space Station, a permanent outpost of humanity in space.The space agency maintains one of the highest profiles of any government-funded scientific body, keeping the world informed about the universe through museum and classroom projects and its award-winning website.

story: Piers Morgan launched into another Twitter spat with Owen Jones (Image: ITVTWITTER)ITV Good Morning Britain host Mr Morgan waded into an argument between the talkRADIO Breakfast Show presenter and political commentator Mr Jones by tweeting: &ldquoOh Owen, stop being so modest! I&rsquove met you both &amp you&rsquore infinitely more unpleasant.It started on Monday when Mr Jones tweeted a video criticising major companies such as British Gas, Experian UK and TK Maxx for advertising with LBC.Mr Jones took issue with companies that advertise with LBC while former Ukip leader Nigel Farage has a slot on the radio station.Mr Jones asked if the brands if they were happy to be associated with LBC when they &ldquolegitimise the rise of &ldquorightwing extremism.He tweeted: &ldquoRightwing extremism&rsquos on the rise - and LBC is legitimising it.&nbsp&ldquoAre major companies like @BritishGas, @Experian_UK and @TKMaxx_UK happy to associate their brands with it?&ldquoWatch this video on how we can #DumpFarage to stop the far-right becoming mainstream.The following day Mrs Hartley-Brewer responded to Mr Jones&rsquo claims by saying he &ldquohe needs help.She tweeted: &ldquoOwen has the look of a man who doesn&rsquot sleep, who is haunted by his demons.&nbsp&ldquoI honestly think he needs help.Mr Jones retaliated and called her &ldquovile and an &ldquounpleasant person.He tweeted: &ldquoSome people think Julia Hartley-Brewer's nastiness is a performance, an act, that she can't really be as vile as she comes across.&nbsp&ldquoI&rsquom afraid she's worse in real life: the most personally unpleasant person with a media platform in Britain. That takes some doing. (Image: )Mr Morgan then put his own two cents into the conversation and gave the  columnist a piece of his mind.It comes after the Good Morning Britain host appeared to cancel an interview with Mr Jones after a Twitter spat earlier this month.&nbspMr Morgan told Mr Jones he was no longer welcome on the ITV breakfast show after he ran a poll asking his 736,000 followers if they believed he should chat to Mr Morgan.Mr Jones seemed to be scheduled to chat to Mr Morgan about Mr Trump&rsquos visit to the UK this morning.Piers Morgan's tweet to Owen Jones (Image: TWITTER)However, following their spat, he was told he was &ldquotoo annoying and his invitation had been rescinded.On Thursday morning, Mr Jones tweeted: &ldquoDo I bother going on Good Morning Britain tomorrow to listen to Piers Morgan verbally masturbating all over himself, or am I wasting my life. Thoughts?He then added a poll, with 52 per ent of 10,381 respondents clicking the &ldquoDo not do it, option.Mr Morgan didn&rsquot waste any time in replying as he hit back: &ldquoNo, you&rsquore too annoying.&ldquoConsider your invitation rescinded &amp go play with your Trump ballon.Mr Jones did not appear on Good Morning Britain that day.

title: ww2 pilot plane bomber pilot reunited with plane somerset
story: Mr Templer made an emotional visit to the RNAS Yeovilton (Image: SWNS)The great-grandad-of-four trained in the biplane in Orkney in 1941 - and later learned squadrons were based their on lookout for Tirpitz battleships travelling between Norway and Denmark to the east.The Swordfish, a torpedo bomber, was tasked with surveilling sea to locate enemy ships or submarines.Mr&nbspTempler&nbspwas deployed to south-east England after training to join a flight of three Swordfish surveilling the coast.The trio were known as the 'String Bags' - because their ordnance was likened to a popular shopping bag used by English women.                WW2 hero Mary Ellis dies aged 101 - tributes for 'legend' and last ...                Italy WW2 bomb THREAT: 12,000 people evacuated after bomb discovere...Mr&nbspTempler&nbsppiloted the Swordfish from Egypt to Malta in 1941 - a 12.5 hour journey which was particularly gruelling because the airplane has an open cockpit.The biplane carries three men - a pilot, navigator and rear gunner - but two embarked on the journey to create space for an extra fuel tank.Mr&nbspTempler&nbspsaid: When I heard the admiralty were recruiting for the fleet air arm in 1940 I jumped at it.There wasn't time to think about the risks involved it was a very hectic time.A biplane carries three people: a pilot, navigator and rear gunner (Image: SWNS)I got my wings at the end of that year and following deck landing training and nightflying training at a pace in May 1941, I was sent to Detling, Kent to join a detached flight of three Swordfish.We supported night time bombardments of the Channel ports. You had a job to do and got on with it.Mr&nbspTempler&nbspbegan flying another torpedo bomber, the Fairey Albacore, in 1942 and was based in Alexandria, North Africa.He retold a hair-raising story a night-flight which nearly saw him crash land in the sea after the navigator got lost. The crew were blinded by darkness during a reconnaissance mission looking for enemy submarines. Their Albacore was carrying depth charges to blow up any targets.Ian also flew a torpedo bomber in 1942 (Image: SWNS)Out of ideas and with the fuel gauge on empty,&nbspMr&nbspTempler&nbspdecided to land in the sea to avoid drifting behind enemy lines and being captured.But the clouds parted and the moon glistened, revealing the runway was closer than they thought and he altered his course.It was at that moment that his engine cut out - but the moon continued to shine and they glided onto the runway to land safely.He said: It was supposed to be a four hour trip but ended up being six as we were on the second leg of sortieThe navigator turned to me and said he was lost which was a shock because he was experienced.I had to figure it out myself - I knew the coastline of North Africa fairly well but needed to find somewhere to land desperately.I didn't want to land behind enemy lines and realised we were very low on fuel.&nbspThe needle was showing empty.I was about to land in the sea - but at that very moment the moon came out from behind the clouds and we had visibility and could see the runway to the right.&nbspWhat luck at 600ft up.I'd never done a ditch landing before so it would have been very wet - and very dangerous.Mr Grey, a pilot in the Fleet Air Arm, said he is 'immensely proud to meet Ian' (Image: SWNS)Mr&nbspTempler's&nbspdaughter, Briony Blair, 65, said of his trip to Yeovilton: It's just fantastic to bring him here today I know how much this means to him and the opportunity to see the Swordfish fly.&nbspWe are immensely proud of him and his contribution all those years ago. Today is both poignant and happy for my Father we are just so delighted to be here.Cdr Nathan Grey, a pilot in the Fleet Air Arm was at the airbase to fly the Swordfish.He said: I feel immensely proud to meet Ian today, what an absolute privilege it is to shake his hand.&nbspTo know what his generation in the Fleet Air Arm achieved in this biplane made of Irish linen during World War Two is truly inspiring and the foundation on which we operate today.It was the first time Ian had been back to Yeovilton since 1944.

title: uk heatwave forecast update london underground tube network air conditioning
story: The heatwave has seen temperatures soar on the London Underground (Image: )The mercury tipped 35C in the southeast on Friday and is threatening to push past the 2003&rsquos record of 38.5C (101.3F) and according to the Met Office, the soaring temperatures are set to stay throughout August.But this will be a nightmare for London&rsquos millions of commuters travelling on the Tube each day, who have endured unbearable heat that has seen the mercury tip 40C.London Underground hit the headlines earlier this week when commuters were left fuming after being told that it will be more than a decade before the introduction of air conditioned trains on one of the Underground&rsquos most popular lines.The Central line held a Q&ampA session on Twitter, which saw, Giovanni Lepori ask: &ldquoThe heat inside trains is reaching levels that are certainly dangerous for elderly people and children. What is being done to solve these unacceptable conditions for which we pay very high prices?In reply, the line&rsquos social media account wrote: &ldquoWe&rsquore aware of the heating issues. We&rsquove made improvements to the ventilation systems on the current fleet.                Rush-hour train chaos: London at a standstill as services CANCELLED                UK heatwave rush hour hell: Commuters face temperatures of 96F&ldquoNew trains are coming in early 2030, under the Deep Tube Upgrade Program, which will be delivered with full air cooling systems.A fleet of 192 air-conditioned, walk-through trains are now running across the Circle, District, politan and Hammersmith and City lines and serving 40 percent of the network, but it may be a while yet before commuters can enjoy this luxury on additional lines.The main reason is because these are sub-surface lines, as opposed to deep-level, and being closer to the surface enables exhausted hot air to be dispersed easily and safely.These four sub-surface lines have larger tunnels that enable air conditioning units to be installed on the trains but the deep-level lines are, at the moment, older and too narrow.There is also a lot of clay surrounding the deep-line tunnels, which traps hot air and results in high temperatures on the likes of the Central and Bakerloo lines.Commuters have been trying to keep cool on the Underground (Image: EPA)The majority of the &lsquoDeep Tube&rsquo network - covering the Jubilee, Northern, Piccadilly, Bakerloo, Central Victoria and Waterloo &amp City lines - were built many decades ago, and are smaller trains that run in two circular tunnels with a diameter of about 11 feet and 8 inches.The lack of space here means there are very few ventilation shafts and so ways to get hot air out and cool air in are limited.The frequency of the trains and the residual heat caused by friction from modern braking systems remains in the tunnel and heats up the train which, when added the UK heatwave the UK is currently experiencing, can make it unbearably hot.The &lsquoDeep Tube programme&rsquo will include new trains that will be cooled, but this could be many years away as the contract to build the new trains was only awarded to Siemens Mobility in June. Twenty-two other UK suppliers have been identified in the bid to potentially work with them.It will see 250 new Tube trains for the Piccadilly, Bakerloo, Central and Waterloo &amp City lines, but the first new walk-through and air conditioned trains won&rsquot be serving the Piccadilly line until 2023.The heat has been particularly uncomfortable during rush hour (Image: )A TfL spokesperson told Express: We completely understand that travelling can be uncomfortable during periods of hot weather and are investing millions of pounds to make the Tube cooler.&ldquoWe are constantly working on new ways to keep the temperature down on the Tube and have doubled the number of fans on the network since 2012 as well as installing chiller units to pump in cold air.&ldquoThere are also 192 air conditioned trains serving 40 per cent of the network.&ldquoDuring this hot weather we advise customers to ensure they have water with them when they travel in order to stay hydrated, offer a seat to those who may need it, and, if they feel ill, to contact a member of staff at the next station.

title: giant sinkhole popular mexico tourist beach
story: A mystery 16 foot wide sinkhole appeared on the beach in Mexico (Image: CENYOUTUBE)The large sinkhole, measuring 5 metres in diameter (16 ft) and 3 metres (10 ft) deep, was seen on the popular tourist beach of Playa del Carmen, in the city of Solidaridad, in the southern Mexican state of Quintana Roo.Bar and restaurant owners reportedly called authorities when they spotted the huge sinkhole on the beach.A man from the area, Julio Cesar Leiva Hernandez, told local media: Friends working there said that a hole started to appear there and it kept getting bigger until it ended up this size.Officers of the Environment department, Civil Protection and Public Security have been to check over the hole, and Environmental Protection Agency (Profepa) have also been notified.Another theory by the locals is that the sinkhole was caused by a stream of fresh water from an underground river.                Burst pipe sends water 30 feet into air as Britain melts in heatwave                Couple whose home was DEMOLISHED by a giant sinkhole awardedBar and restaurant owners called authorities when they spotted the huge sinkhole on the beach (Image: CENYOUTUBE)According to local media, this kind of natural phenomenon is not unknown in the Mayan Riviera.The nearby Punta Esmeralda is where two fresh waters currents meet, making one of the most important and touristic spa areas of Playa del Carmen.Leiva Hernandez added: This area is full of natural wells, this is the eye where the water flow concentrates.&ldquoThere is another one in Punta Esmeralda that started just like this one, it started to open until it made a large fresh water pool.The local resident believes the sinkhole should be left to grow so that nature can take its course instead of being filled with sand as they usually do.

title: dr sarah wollaston column save lives
story: It is a crime which blights the lives of victims and can cause devastating psychological and physical harm.And it is a crime that also costs lives, with a significant risk of escalation to murder.The statistics are alarming.In a 2017 study by the University of Gloucestershire, based on 358 criminal homicides, stalking behaviour was identified in the run-up to 94 PER CENT of the murders.And stalking is getting easier. The spread of social media and other online communication, with its inherent anonymity, has only increased the misery for victims.But the speed of change has not been matched by a more robust framework to deal with it.Yes, we have tougher sentences — the Government was absolutely right to last year double jail terms for the worst cases from five to ten years.But progress has been too slow in recognising these crimes.In 2016-17, fewer than 1,000 prosecutions were commenced under stalking legislation.It was horrifying to read the account of Nicola Roberts from Girls Aloud yesterday.She told how she faced a barrage of more than 3,000 texts over five years from an ex-boyfriend, including threats to stab and burn her.Soon after being handed a lifetime restraining order, her ex began following her on Instagram.He “wanted me to know he was still watching me”, she said, chillingly.And yet the CPS saw no realistic chance of a successful prosecution for stalking because the social media activity was not taken sufficiently seriously, despite the obvious impact on Nicola’s life.As she put it: “I should be able to move on from an unhealthy relationship if I want and that’s not been able to happen.”She wants change — and she is right to.These kinds of messages leave you in fear for your life — feeling that someone is watching or following you is immensely distressing.A bunch of flowers is not a romantic gesture when sent by a stalker but a reminder that your persecutor is still watching and can still reach you.Stalking is a crime of obsession and fixation and it needs to be stopped before it becomes deeply ingrained.No legislation will be effective unless it is accompanied by training at the front line of policing and across the wider courts system.Victims must have the confidence to come forward at an earlier stage, for all forms of stalking to be recognised for what they are. It is my intention to make this happen.My Stalking Protection Bill will introduce so-called Stalking Protection Orders (SPOs) to help fill some of the gaps in the law.It will allow the police to act more quickly and to protect victims of so-called stranger stalking, where the stalker is not a former partner.Importantly, it will also take the onus off the victim to have to take action, as is currently the case for stranger stalking. At present many victims are left unprotected because they have to put protective measures in place for themselves, such as applying for a civil injunction to restrain someone from harassing them.Needless to say, many victims find this such a daunting task — not to mention expensive and time-consuming — that they end up not going through with it.If passed, the Stalking Protection Bill would allow the police to apply for an SPO through the magistrates’ courts on behalf of victims.Orders will require the civil standard of proof “on the balance of probabilities” but breach of an order would be a criminal offence, punishable in the most serious cases by a term of up to five years in prison.SPOs could set out requirements prohibiting certain behaviours, such as contacting the victim either directly or indirectly.It would be able to prohibit behaviours such as driving past the victim’s house, harassing friends, colleagues or family members, going within a certain distance of the victim or following them online.It could also set out so called positive requirements, such as attending a psychiatric assessment.In this digital age, the law would cover online contact from abroad and require that any IT equipment would be free from encryption, so perpetrators could not cover their tracks.Unlike the now-abandoned Police Information Notices, SPOs will have teeth, as they would be enforceable and breaching the terms of an order would have consequences.SPOs would also require stalkers to register all the names they use, as well as their address.While SPOs will provide better early intervention to protect victims, they are not intended to replace full prosecution for an offence of stalking.They will, however, enable police to better protect the safety of victims while gathering the full evidence for the CPS to prosecute a full stalking case.The Bill has almost completed its Commons journey but will not now return to the Chamber until late November.When the case for change is so pressing, and the Bill is backed by members across the House, I believe the Government should bring forward the final Commons stage so we can get on with delivering this vital change to the law — which will help to save lives.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: top ten irritants summer heatwave jane moore
story: First and foremost being the Met Office’s “Amber Alert” warning to stay in the shade, drink plenty of fluids and be sure to wear sunscreen and dark glasses.Come winter, of course, they’ll once again be treating us all like morons and doom-mongering about slippery pavements and hypothermia.Luckily for them, new research revealing the top ten list of what irritates us came out before their nannying nonsense and, therefore, a “sorry we missed you” note took first place, followed by the whirring wheel on a computer and losing work you didn’t save.Life’s irritants, eh? Oh, let me count the ways. And believe me, it goes waaaay past ten.In fact, there are so many I feel it easier to group them together under various categories. So here goes.Eat with their mouths open stop an interesting group conversation to tell a dull, long-winded story with no point to it are overweight but claim they barely eat anything are thin but claim they eat everything pepper every, like, sentence with, like, the word “like” (Exhibit A: Anyone on Love Island) noisily slurp drinks in the cinema don’t pick up their dog’s poo make every sentence sound like a question litter the countryside don’t control their children in public places barge on to a train while you’re trying to get off read over your shoulder put bags on seats park in disabled bays when they’re clearly not live in a trillion quid mansion but claim to be socialist are glued to their mobile phone while their kid hurtles towards a road junction on its micro scooterupload ALL their holiday photos on social media, even the really crap ones say “aaah” loudly after drinking something.Aaaaaargh!Passengers who applaud when a flight lands parents who allow their kids to continually kick the back of your seat for the duration of a flight airport/rail managers who fail to boost staff numbers at peak times of the year oncoming drivers who push their way down a narrow road when you’re already three­quarters of the way along it train passengers who talk loudly on a mobile phone or think everyone else wants to listen to their ghastly music too people who cough on a crowded Tube/train without covering their mouth tailgaters drivers who don’t say thank you when you let them in middle lane hoggers packing hand luggage for a quick exit and being forced to put it in the hold.Head lice (so pointless) “Smart” TVs that make you feel anything but when trying to use the damned things novelty ringtones printed signs with spelling errors (use a pigging dictionary)online sites that won’t accept your usual password because it doesn’t have 48 squillion characters in it packaging that Harry Houdini would struggle to open roadworks with no one working on them spam emails automated phone systems immovable price stickers.Passing waiters who, when you ask for something simple like a spoon, reply: “Hang on, I’ll just get your waiter for you” shop assistants who stalk you around the rails as if you’re about to nick something fellow shoppers who start turning the rack of cards while you’re still looking at it hairdressers who chat incessantly through the supposedly “relaxing” head massage bit waiters who automatically hand the bill to the man queue-pushers at the bar bags “for life” that break the second you leave the supermarket assistants who carry on their social chat while you stand at the till waiting to be served cashiers who comment, “Ooh, are you having a party?”when you’re buying your own weekly wine supply shoppers who abuse the “ten items or less” aisle. Unless it’s me, of course.Believe me, I’m just scratching the surface here.Send me your irritations and I’ll print the best next week.Meghan Markles unpleasant half-sister Samantha is at it again – this time berating her understandably estranged royal relative for paying tribute to Nelson Mandela.“How about you pay tribute to your own father?” she ranted. “Enough is enough.Act like a humanitarian, act like a woman.If our father dies, I’m holding you responsible, Meg.”What a Grade A nasty.Meanwhile, last week Meghan’s father Thomas spent his 74th birthday picking up a Happy Meal from fast-food joint McDonald’s.Which, considering he’s just had heart stents fitted to help clear clogged arteries, suggests that if he dies any time soon, the only person responsible would be him.High-end designer ­Burberry junks £28million of unwanted products each year.A Burberry source has denied claims that they don’t donate it to charity because they don’t want the “wrong people” ­wearing it, saying that the destruction is actually to ­protect the brand against counterfeiting. Hmmm.The fakes ­market will always ­flourish irrespective of how many originals are pulped.So why doesn’t ­Burberry donate the items to upmarket charity ­auctions where people can bid a lot of money for something they might have bought anyway and have the extra thrill of knowing their cash will go to a deserving cause?Model David Gandy says he was once chucked out of a Hugo Boss catwalk show “because I couldn’t fit any of the clothing”.But luckily for the legion of Mr Gandy’s female fans, he can clearly still squeeze his, ahem, lardy self in to a teeny tiny pair of ­Y-fronts.Nope, still not going to wear them.Former Olympic showjumper Lizzie Purbrick has been telling her side of the story after being convicted of criminal damage for spraying her former lover’s home with several litres of pig’s blood.As you do.Lizzie, 63, says that initially, her relationship with Tory peer Lord Prior was “bloody marvellous” after they “met at a dinner party in Norfolk – the hotbed of sex – and I moved in with him four days later.”Whoa. Hang on, rewind that. Genteel Norfolk a hotbed of sex?And lo and behold, two days after this revelation, a survey by our sister paper The Sun on Sunday revealed that the nookie capital of Britain is…drum roll…Norfolk.So quite what they’re putting in the water up there is anyone’s guess.But something tells me house prices are suddenly set to rise.Charlie, 45, told his brother Matthew on the phone: “I’d really like to go out for a bottle of wine. I’ve been let out for a cigarette but I’m very bored.”We’ll take that as a no, then.Activity badges for Guides, Rangers and Brownies have been revamped for the 21st Century.You’ll be relieved to know Moped Mugging isn’t one of them, but there’s “Mixology” which involves designing a menu of non-alcoholic cocktails, “Festival Goer”, Vlogging, Mindfulness, Human Rights, Conscious ­Consumer and Media Critic (everyone’s a bloody critic.) Cripes.During my brief time as a Brownie in the late Sixties, I only achieved the “Hostess” badge, which entailed making a cup of tea for some visiting dignitaries at our local community centre and helping an elderly woman across the road.She didn’t want to go but, hey, a badge is a badge.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hostile eu uk daniel hannan opinion
story: Most Britons, whether they voted Remain or Leave, hoped that we would replace EU ­membership with a close alliance.Pulling out of the Brussels institutions did not need to prejudice friendly relations with our neighbours.But it is becoming clear that Eurocrats do not see it that way. The 27 EU states, or most of them at any rate, might individually want good relations with us.But, in Brussels, there are plenty of officials who would rather see all sides suffer than watch Brexit succeed.If their view prevails, the implications go well beyond Brexit. For 70 years, Britain has been a European power.Although we kept our military ties with the other English-speaking democracies, our focus was the defence of Europe. It still is.There are, for example, British soldiers patrolling the borders of Poland and Estonia.The RAF is, to all intents and purposes, acting as Romania’s air force, responding to incursions into that country’s airspace. And so on.In intelligence and security, rather as with the Common Fisheries Policy, Britain puts a lot more than its share into the common pot.We have done so cheerfully because we saw European states as our allies, and felt that we had a stake in their security. But what if that feeling is no longer reciprocated?Visiting Germany on Monday, Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, pointed out in measured and polite language that the EU could not expect to treat Britain aggressively without consequences.Now Mr Hunt is no Little Englander. He is an entrepreneur who made his money from language courses, is married to a Chinese woman and, after some soul-searching, came down on the side of Remain.But what he said is impossible to argue with. If the EU chooses to treat Brexit as a hostile act, the basis of European security will be undone — at the very moment that Donald Trump has made it clear that America is no longer interested in defending Europe.In almost every European speech since the referendum, Theresa May has said that she wants Britain to be the EU’s closest friend and strongest ally.But when have you ever heard those good wishes returned?The PM keeps saying she wants the EU 27 to succeed. EU leaders keep saying they want Brexit to fail.They mean it. Eurocrats are not offering Britain the kind of deal that they have with neighbours such as Norway and Switzerland.They think UK will just swallow what’s offered.If we want to remain in the single market, says chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier, then, unlike those countries, we’d have to give Brussels 100 per cent control of our trade policy — an impossible condition.But neither are they offering the kind of simple free trade deal that they have with, say, Canada and Japan.If we want a straightforward trade deal, Barnier says, we’d have to leave Northern Ireland under EU rules — an equally impossible condition.In other words, Britain won’t be allowed the friendly relations with the EU that other democracies take for granted.It is not for a lack of willingness on our side. In February, Theresa May told a Munich audience: “Europe’s security is our security. And that is why I say that the United Kingdom is unconditionally committed to maintaining it.”The EU’s response? To exclude us from the Galileo satellite programme on grounds that we could no longer be trusted.Well, fine. I never saw much point in the Galileo system, which was pushed by French leader Jacques Chirac to challenge the “technological imperialism” of America’s GPS system.Britain should now either go in with the Americans or create its own satellite system, possibly with friendly states such as Australia and Canada.But the point is, the EU’s logic goes well beyond satellites.If Brussels no longer sees us as an ally, we can hardly carry on behaving like one unilaterally, so to speak.While we talk of trade and co-operation, EU negotiators talk of border queues and grounded flights.Ireland’s prime minister, Leo Varadkar, even threatens to close his airspace.If such thinking wins out, we shall have no choice but to leave Europe to itself and turn our faces, as our ancestors did, to the open seas.That is not an outcome anyone should want, but we shall be ready if it comes.Understandably enough, you might say, given what feeble negotiators we have been so far. But Britain has a bad habit of switching from vague amiability to sudden resolve when it is almost too late.Such a moment is upon us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
